scenarioDescription:
The K2-79 Exoplanetary System


Overview

K2-79 is a star with 1.06 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.28 times its radius. It is located 835.00 light years away from the solar system.

K2-79 is known to have 1 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the K2-79 system


K2-79 b

K2-79 b was discovered by the K2 observatory, in 2016-09, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of K2-79 b is 13.197 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-79 b is 3.690 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, K2-79 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system K2-79, which contains 1 exoplanets and was discovered by the K2.
name: K2-79 - System With 1 Exoplanet
